title: Trump promises 100 percent tariff on movies ‘produced in foreign lands’
summary:
President Donald Trump says his administration will institute high tariffs on movies that fit the nebulous category of "produced in foreign lands," a definition that could include anything from anime to the latest Marvel films.

In a Sunday evening Truth Social post, Trump claimed that "Other Countries are offering all sorts of incentives to draw our filmmakers and studios away from the United States," something that constituted "a concerted effort by other Nations and, therefore, a National Security threat." (Capitalization in original.) To change this, Trump declared that he was authorizing the Department of Commerce and the United States Trade Representative to begin adding a 100 percent tariff to "any and all Movies coming into our Country that are produced in Foreign Lands."

Like many of Trump's tariff proposals, the post creates a cloud of uncertainty over a huge swathe of American consumer goods. If the plan is carried out, the US could theoretically attempt to tax anyone who imports a foreign film into the US. ## Trump Promises 100 Percent Tariff on Movies ‘Produced in Foreign Lands’  

Former President Donald Trump announced plans to impose a 100% tariff on movies "produced in foreign lands," a broad category that could include major Hollywood films like Marvel blockbusters. In a Truth Social post, Trump framed the move as a response to foreign incentives luring filmmakers away from the U.S., calling it a "National Security threat." The proposal, if enacted, could apply to films shot partially or entirely abroad, creating uncertainty for the entertainment industry.  

### Why It Matters  

This proposal could significantly disrupt the film industry, where many big-budget productions rely on international locations for cost efficiency or creative authenticity. A 100% tariff might force studios to reconsider filming abroad, potentially raising production costs and affecting ticket prices. The vague definition of "foreign-produced" also leaves room for legal challenges, especially for films with multinational production teams. Given Hollywood's global footprint, this policy could strain U.S. trade relations and reshape how movies are made.
